TXT4Tots Message: {name} is 1 now :birthday:, CONGRATULATIONS!
:point_right: Don't forget it's time for {name}'s 1 year checkup! The Dr. will talk to you about how {name} is growing & what to expect this year.
Now that {name} is 1 he/she can start drinking milk :baby_bottle:! For most kids ages 1-2, whole milk is usually best. Talk to the Dr. about what milk to drink.
Is {name} :baby: still breastfeeding? Great! Continue breastfeeding as long as mom & child enjoy it, visit http://bit.ly/r7HioU
:clap: Celebrate this week! Now that {name} is 1, he/she is ready to drink from a cup instead of a bottle. Have fun picking out a big kid cup.
Letting {name} feed himself/herself during meals can help from over-eating. Put down a towel for an easy cleanup.
It's true, you are {name}'s super hero! :heart: Tell {name} what YOU eat to get the best super hero energy. It may sound funny but kids love it!
Parenting is a busy job! Take time when you grocery shop to pick out easy to eat on-the-go healthy snacks like a banana :banana: or whole grain cereal.
Don't forget it's time for {name}'s 15 month well child visit! Bring questions about temper tantrums & picky eating!
We know you're a family on the go, but try to only dine out :knife_fork_plate: once a week. If dining out, try chicken (or equivalent) :poultry_leg: and pick fruit :green_apple: as a side.
Lowfat milk :baby_bottle: & water :droplet: are the best drink choices for {name}, but we all need variety! Limit sugar-sweetened drinks like soda to special occasions.
Do your kids drink juice? :watermelon: :grape: :pineapple: Here are some tips 1) Make sure its 100% fruit juice (without added sugar) 2) Keep it to 4-6 oz (120-180 mL) a day.
Toddlers like to copy everything you do. Demonstrate healthy habits you want them to learn like eating fruit for snacks & walking :walking: after dinner.
Need some ideas for active games? Your childcare provider will have ideas or visit http://bit.ly/1FnDhpu for suggestions on physical activities.
If {name} can shovel sand, he/she can be taught to serve himself/herself food. :knife_fork_plate: He/She might be a little messy at first but this is an important skill!
Activity idea! Play freeze dance. :dancer: Put on {name}'s favorite music :notes: and take turns turning it off and on!
Children on the move and eating don't mix! Help prevent choking by making sure {name} sits down when eating or drinking. Visit http://bit.ly/Ra18iX
You are not alone! Almost every toddler has a picky eating phase. Tips: 1) Try to be patient 2) Give healthy food 3) Talk to other parents for tips.
Did you know that some kids fill up on beverages :tropical_drink: & then don't want to try eating new foods. If you are trying out a new food give it with water :droplet:.
Its time for {name}'s 18 month well child :baby: visit! Bring your questions about {name}'s behavior & vocabulary.
Did you know toddlers :baby: may need to try a new food 10-15 times over several months, sounds like a lot right! Visit http://bit.ly/NgphPp for ideas.
Involve childcare in your healthy lifestyle. Plan together on ways that will encourage healthy habits. For ideas, visit http://bit.ly/Ra18iX
Sometimes it seems harder to be active inside, but you can do it! Tips: 1) Play hide and seek 2) Create an obstacle course with pillows.
Not all families :man-woman-girl-boy: will agree on what is the best to feed their child. If you can't agree, YOU can feed {name} healthy food and beverages.
Serving sizes for toddlers are much smaller. A serving of vegetables :eggplant: is 1-2 Tablespoons, the size of a quarter. Eating ideas: http://bit.ly/Ra18iX
Don't feel pressured to make more than 1 meal at dinner. {name} will eat the healthy meal you've made if he/she is truly hungry.
Snacking on the run? :runner: Keep lowfat cheese sticks, bananas, and small, whole grain crackers on hand. 2-3 snacks a day can help prevent temper tantrums.
Have a hard time getting {name} to sit & eat? Tip: 1) Have mealtimes at the same time :clock2: each day so {name} knows when its mealtime.
Parents of 1yr olds often say my child is such a picky eater! True for you? You are not alone! Visit http://bit.ly/P6Nvy8 for ideas.
Talk to your childcare provider today about how much active play {name} is getting a day. Work together & make sure {name} is staying active.
Being a parent is an important job. Start each day with a healthy breakfast. :stew:
Snack idea! Ask your parents & grandparents what their favorite healthy snacks were as a child. Try making it & tell {name}. :egg:
Get support! Playdates with families from {name}'s daycare or school :school: can be great! You can share info about picky eating & new food ideas.
Do YOUR parents have an activity they like to do? Encourage them to teach this to {name}. It will provide great memories.
Toddlers need lots of room to jump & play! Cover outlets & gate stairways to keep play area safe.
Snacks are important for healthy eating. Limit to 2-3 so {name} has room for meals.
Fruits :grapes: and veggies are healthy snacks! Cut grapes in half and chop carrots finely or into thin strips before giving to {name} to prevent choking.
Start them early, its easier to get kids in the habit of eating & enjoying whole grains when they're young. For more info watch: http://bit.ly/MVyFqx
If {name} only wants to eat 1 food, keep serving that food with other healthy food. They'll move on eventually! For ideas: http://bit.ly/NgphPp
Has {name}'s doctor recommended less 100% fruit juice & more water :droplet: ? Explain to your family the importance of this change.
Did you hear "clean your plate" :fork_and_knife: when you were growing up? Now Drs. know it leads to kids over eating, for more information visit: http://bit.ly/IAElG9
What you eat and do is important. Practice the healthy habits you want your family to have for life. Visit www.myplate.gov for healthy eating ideas.
:point_right: Don't forget its time for {name}'s 2 year well child visit! Bring your questions about {name}'s activity level.
Be patient with family members who offer unhealthy choices to {name}. It's really hard! Try packing food for {name} if it makes sense.
Talk to your family about healthy food and drink choices for {name}. Ask them what healthy choices you liked as a kid & what they did with you.
Happy 2nd Birthday! :gift: Congratulations on making it to the 2's in such a healthy way! Enjoy celebrating today.
Time to switch to lower fat milk, try 2% fat milk :baby_bottle: for a few weeks then switch to 1%, then try fat-free milk. Watch: http://bit.ly/LD4j08 for more info.
Breakfast can help us better manage our hunger and avoid eating junk food. :pizza: Whole-grain toast :bread:, an egg :egg: & lowfat cheese (or equivalent) :cheese_wedge: can be breakfast on the go.
Does {name}'s school offer a parent group? :family: This is a great way to share feeding ideas and struggles with other parents.
It's important for children to listen to their body. Turning away or refusing to eat may be {name} saying he/she is full. Info: http://bit.ly/Ra18iX
If you need a break and want to let {name} watch TV, set a timer for 30 minutes :timer_clock:. You can get a lot done & know how much time he/she watched TV :tv:.
Sometimes family members just can't believe little kids like healthy food! Invite your family over to eat to see how much he/she is enjoying healthy foods.
Going out this weekend? :beach_with_umbrella: Have fun! Give the sitter a list of {name}'s favorite activities.
While watching TV :tv: with your 2 yr old, take commercial breaks to add activities. Hula-hoop, dance :dancers: or have a hopping contest.
Did you know that half of {name}'s plate at each meal should be fruits & veggies? For info visit http://www.choosemyplate.gov/preschoolers.html
Feel {name} is always moving? Fantastic! Activities like running :runner:, dancing :dancer:, and climbing are SO important for muscle and brain growth.
Check in with your childcare provider! Ask how many fruits & veggies {name} is getting at daycare. Check the menu for ideas to make at home.
Snack time is a great time to try new foods, since you are giving kids just a little bit, you avoid wasting. Is it a new food? Start with a spoonful.
What is {name}'s favorite activity at childcare? Try playing it at home :house_with_garden: tonight, let {name} show you how to do it.
Activity idea! Name animals for {name} to pretend to be. Act it out together by hopping like a rabbit :rabbit2: or running like a cheetah :tiger2:.
Need a great idea to get {name} to drink more water :droplet: ? Let him/her pick his/her own "big kid" cup with a fun character. Keep this cup for water only.
Eating on the go? Make sure {name} isn't eating in the car :car: while you're driving because you won't be able to help if choking occurs.
Feeding {name} 3 meals and 2 snacks at regular times each day can help prevent hunger temper tantrums.
Healthy habits start now! Need ideas on how to feed your family healthy and while on a budget, visit: http://1.usa.gov/rXb8gD
:city_sunset: Evening routines help the family unwind from a busy day & {name} go to bed :couch_and_lamp: easier, try reading a book :open_book: or listen to a favorite song :musical_note: together.
Does your childcare provider have regular naptimes? Check in and see how {name} is sleeping, so you can make sure he/she is getting enough sleep. :sleeping:
Toddlers stomachs are small. Give small portions of several healthy foods and let them ask for more. This prevents getting full on just one food.
Giving options can reduce power struggles. Provide two healthy choices such as a banana :banana: or apple :apple: & then let {name} choose!
Don't forget its time for {name}'s 2 1/2 year well child visit! Bring all your questions about starting pre-school & playing with other kids.
Make vegetables fun! When eating carrots, act like rabbits. :rabbit: Wiggle your noses and make rabbit noises. For menu ideas visit: http://1.usa.gov/FQy6JE
Kids ages 2-3 need 2- 2.5 cups of lowfat milk daily. To make sure your family gets enough, keep lowfat yogurt and cheese :cheese_wedge: in the fridge as well.
Playing is important to the way {name} learns & stays active. Talk to everyone that takes care of {name} & make sure they know your wishes.
Need some snack or meal ideas for {name}? 1) Ask parent friends with toddlers 2) Try these recipes bit.ly/kncWDG
{name} may be irritable when hungry and play with food :cookie: when full. It is helpful to provide meals and snacks at regular times.
TV :tv: commercials often feature high fat & sugary foods. :chocolate_bar: Keep control by playing a video or using On Demand to skip commercials.
Take time today to celebrate all the healthy choices you've made for your family. You are really shaping {name}'s healthy habits for life!
Need some menu ideas? Visit http://1.usa.gov/FQy6JE for menu and snack ideas for 2 year olds.
Healthy physical activity habits can start anytime but are easier to set as a kid. Make time for 1 hour of activity & 1 hour of play each day.
Being a parent is a busy job. Try adding exercise to your day by taking the stairs or parking the car :blue_car: far away from the store entrance.
Does {name} play with food? Maybe he/she is full! It can be frustrating but don't pressure him/her to eat more. Ideas: http://bit.ly/Ra18iX
Be careful to spread peanut butter thinly on crackers or bread :bread:. Peanut butter can cause choking if too thick or if just eaten off the spoon.
It may seem like toddlers are always on the move! Have a favorite activity you like to do--start taking him/her along!
Activity idea! Have a parade today. March or dance along to music around the house. Let {name} be the leader too.
Tell your family about your healthy living goals. Suggest ways to help like water :droplet: instead of fruit drinks :tropical_drink:. Tips: http://bit.ly/Ra18iX
You are a great role model. Show your preschooler the healthy choices you make by snacking on fruits and veggies together. Ideas: http://1.usa.gov/wVvzKz
What you eat and do as a parent is SO important. Learn how to keep eating positive!
Does your childcare provide time for play? Ask what kinds of activities they do to keep {name} moving.
Activity idea! Play follow-the-leader! Let {name} be the leader too. March, crawl or dance for fun. More activity ideas: http://bit.ly/Ra18iX
Some medications :pill: can affect {name}'s hunger or even how well he/she can digest food. Talk to his/her pediatrician about any new medications.
Did you know a can of soda can have up to 3 TBS of sugar! Limit drinks such as soda and 100% fruit juice. You can offer water :droplet: or lowfat milk :baby_bottle: instead.

100% fruit juice :tropical_drink: has natural sugars than can damage teeth. Limit to 4-6 oz (120-180 mL) daily. Try water :droplet: with fruit slices :watermelon: instead. More ideas: http://bit.ly/Ra18iX
:point_right: Don't forget it's time to schedule {name}'s 3 year well child visit! Bring all your questions about keeping {name} as active as possible.
Your preschooler may start fighting nap time. Change his/her nap into quiet time. Read books :open_book: or have him/her quietly play in his/her room with toys :dolls:.
Did you know, frozen veggies have as many vitamins & mineral as fresh veggies. Choose packs that are just veggies with no added fat or salt.
You should try and make at least half of the grains you eat whole grains.
Happy 3rd Birthday! :birthday: :jack_o_lantern: Congratulations We hope you have a WONDERFUL day celebrating today.
Did you know that low-fat (1%) or fat free (skim) milk provides the same vitamins as whole milk but without the extra fat?
Half of {name}'s plate :knife_fork_plate: should be filled with fruits & vegetables at each meal.
Did you know? Head Start is an early education program for low-income families :man-woman-girl-boy: with children ages birth to five.
Have {name} ask permission before getting a snack. You can stay in control of what and how much he/she eats. Snack ideas: 1.usa.gov/FQy6JE
Your childcare provider might have great tips to encourage healthy foods with {name}. Talk about ways you can work together.
Are you comfortable with the messages from {name}'s TV shows :tv: ? Try to preview shows in advance or watch the show with {name}.
Having a mealtime, playtime and bedtime routine can help you stay in control. This also helps {name} know what to expect each day.
3 yr olds love to explore! Visit your local or state park.
Fruit drink :tropical_drink: & soda add unneeded calories which can lead to extra weight gain later in {name}'s life. Skim or low-fat milk :baby_bottle: & water :droplet: are best.
Show {name} how important fruits :pear:, veggies :eggplant:, and lean meats :meat_on_bone: are by filling your plate with these healthy choices. Visit http://www.myplate.gov
Be creative :thinking_face: at mealtime. Use your fruits and veggies to make a story with your preschooler. Broccoli can be a tree, celery a boat.
Fighting a picky eater can be a real challenge; have your picky eater help you make the meal. Let them set the table or clean the vegetables.
Take your preschooler food shopping :shopping_bags: with you. Let them pick a new food to try tonight. They may be more willing to try it.
Many preschoolers like to snack on food all day rather than stop playing. But giving meals at regular times can keep them from over-eating.
If you choose to serve 100% fruit juice, limit to 4-6 ounces (120-180 mL) a day. Mark a line on the cup to show how much should be poured.
Feel like you're always on the go? Visit http://1.usa.gov/sJEESB for ideas :bulb: to eat healthy while you are eating out.
Does {name}'s school offer a parent group? Its a great way to share ideas :bulb: and struggles with other parents. More ideas: http://bit.ly/Ra18iX
Serving a new food? Try not to make a big deal about it. Put it on {name}'s plate as part of the meal. :knife_fork_plate: Need menu ideas, visit: 1.usa.gov/FQy6JE
Remind grandparents the doctor says active playing is good for building muscles :muscle: and learning. Help create activities they can do with {name}.
As a family, set limits and rules for the TV :tv:, computer :computer:, smart phone :iphone:, and video games :video_game:. Try to keep these off during mealtime.
Create an activity chart with {name}. Track active play time at home :house_with_garden: or childcare with stickers for each activity. Think of a fun reward!
Having trouble getting your preschooler to drink water :droplet: instead of 100% juice? Add colorful fruit slices :watermelon: to make water fun!
Let {name} pick healthy snacks at the grocery store :department_store:.
A zoo day is a great family activity. Help your preschooler name all the animals :point_right: :frog: :dog: :panda_face: and try to save the stroller for nap time.
Candy :candy: and sugary drinks :tropical_drink: can be fun treats but try to limit these to special occasions. It is important to save room for healthy foods.
Try using a cookie cutter to cut a sandwich into different shapes. A picky eater may be more willing to try a star or triangle sandwich.
Ask {name}'s teacher for help in making sure your preschooler gets enough physical activity during the day. :bulb: More ideas: http://bit.ly/Ra18iX
Snacks can be fast and healthy. Orange slices, whole grain crackers and peanut butter or carrot slices are healthy and easy on the go!
{name} is becoming more independent. Giving choices between 2-3 healthy foods can help you stay in control at mealtime.
Watching TV :tv: close to bedtime can affect {name}'s ability to sleep. Keep TV out of the bedroom so he/she gets a restful night sleep. :sleeping:
Make snack time fun! Use fresh fruits :peach: and veggies :eggplant: to teach your preschooler their colors. :bulb: More ideas and tips for healthy eating: http://bit.ly/Ra18iX
Preschoolers love to learn and get dirty. Start your own garden or join a community garden :national_park:.
If you ever feel down about your health choices, you can start today. Try as a family to set a new healthy goal each month. Make the 1st one easy.
Keep quick, healthy snacks such as lowfat or fat-free yogurt, cheese sticks or granola bars on hand.
Be clear with your childcare provider about your family's TV rules. Talk about ways they can turn off the TV :tv: while {name} is with them.
Include family and friends into your healthy habits. Ask for help to find ways to add active play time for your preschooler. :bulb: Ideas: http://bit.ly/Ra18iX
What are {name}'s favorite games to play? Find out and play as a family :family:. It can be a great way to add exercise to your day.
Let your preschooler choose his/her snack today. Offer fruit, veggies, whole grain crackers, lowfat cheese? Talk to {name} about the snack he/she chose!
Help {name} understand that people come in many sizes and shapes. He/She should never tease or bully another child for being different.
{name} has lots of energy and loves to be active. Make sure you're near him/her while playing so you can supervise and help if needed.
Talk to {name}'s doctor (not to {name}) about any concerns of weight or size. It is important to show love and support for {name}!
Try directing your preschooler's play. Offer more challenging play such as kicking a ball back :person_with_ball: and forth to help build new skills.
Fruit offers health benefits like fiber and vitamins. Try this calculator to see how much fruit {name} needs a day: http://1.usa.gov/MCnUMA
Check in! Talk to {name}'s teacher about the healthy food and drink choices you want {name} to be eating & drinking at school.
Be honest with your family about your healthy living goals. Suggest ways they can help with activities or introducing healthy foods they like.
As a parent it's important not to tease {name} about his/her weight or size (even if you are kidding). If you have concerns talk to his/her doctor.
Help grandparents think of healthy ways to spoil your kids. Creating an art project :art: together can be a great way to include grandparents.
{name} watches what drinks you choose. Make healthy choices for yourself! Like soda? Try replacing soda with water :droplet:.
All children need physical activity. If {name} has special health care needs, talk to {name}'s doctor about ways he/she can be active.
Family members love {name} too. Offer ideas for games or play activities they can do together when {name} is in their care.
:point_right: Don't forget its time for {name}'s 4 year well child visit! Bring all your questions about getting ready for school.
Share advice from {name}'s doctor with your family. This may help them get on board with your healthy lifestyle goals.
:bulb: Activity idea! Set up a scavenger hunt :sleuth_or_spy: in your home. Ask your preschooler to skip, hop or crawl to find the items you have hidden.
Did you know that having a TV in {name}'s bedroom can affect how well they sleep? Consider having a TV :tv: only in the family room.
Happy 4th Birthday! :birthday: :gift: We hope you have a fun filled day today!!!
You're busy! Keep up with {name} by eating plenty of fresh fruits and veggies. See how many fruits & veggies you need: http://1.usa.gov/MCnUMA
What was your favorite game or song as a child? Play or dance to it with your family tonight.
Creating a regular routine now for meals and snacks can help your preschooler learn and keep healthy habits later in life.
Breakfast helps children learn and behave better at school. Oatmeal, fruit and lowfat yogurt and whole grain cereals are nutritious and quick.
Family meals are a great way to build healthy habits and share your day. Try to schedule a time once a day :clock930: for your family to eat together.
Need healthy menu ideas for your 4 year old? Visit http://1.usa.gov/FQy6JE
Time spent watching TV :tv: or playing video games :video_game: can replace important exercise for your preschooler. Make sure to set aside time to be active.
Being healthy is important for every member of the family, including you. Take care of yourself. Start each day with a healthy breakfast.
Safety tip! Look for outdoor playgrounds that have rubber matting or sand :beach_with_umbrella:. These protect kids from getting hurt from a fall but keep them active!
Eating directly out of a box or container can allow for overeating. Make sure to serve food from a plate, bowl, or dish :knife_fork_plate:.
Nutrition labels can offer helpful information. Look at serving size, sugar content, sodium, and calories from fat when choosing foods.
Swimming :swimmer: is a great activity for the whole family. Look for community pools or YMCAs for year round family fun. Always stay within arms reach!
Did you know {name} should be active for at least 1 hour a day? Invite kids from the neighborhood over to play tag in the backyard!
:bulb: Activity idea! Instead of watching TV :tv: try one of these ideas: 1) build a fort 2) dance or 3) play hide and seek.
Healthy habits can include the entire family :man-woman-girl-boy:. Make small changes such as drinking water :droplet: instead of soda or buy fruit :tangerine: instead of chips.
Many communities offer leagues for young children to start sports like soccer :football: or t-ball. Ask your doctor or neighbors where to sign up.
Your 4yr old is getting stronger and building motor skills through play. Play red-light-green-light :traffic_light: or tag to test their new skills.
Children snacking in the car :car: can limit a parent's control of the amount. Try to wait until you can watch how much {name} is eating.
A rainy day :rain_cloud: is a great time for a museum visit. Let your 4 year old walk instead of riding in the stroller.
Community and faith-based centers :pray: can be a safe place for activity. Look at your local library for resources in your community.
On the go? Whole fruit is a great snack to eat at the park or at the mall. Put oranges or bananas in your bag for a quick snack.
Fresh, frozen & canned fruits & vegetables can be smart choices. Don't forget to look at the label and stock up when they go on sale.
Did you know, frozen and canned veggies have as many vitamins & mineral as fresh veggies. Choose packs that are just veggies with no added fat, salt.
You should try and make at least half of the grains you eat whole grains.
Happy kids, happy tummies. Serve favorite whole grain breads, cereals & pasta, whole grains high in fiber can make potty time easier too.
Let kids learn by serving themselves. Teach them to take small amounts & let them know they can get more if hungry.
Need more milk :baby_bottle:? Try making smoothies by blending together 1% milk, fruit :grape: and low-fat yogurt or make oatmeal with 1% milk instead of water.
Incorporate physical activity into your daily routine; If possible walk with {name} to do an errand or visit a neighbor.
Being active every day is important to keep your family healthy. Check your local recreation center for planned activities or plan something yourself.
Finding time to be physically active can be hard. Turn on music :notes: and get the whole family dancing :dancers: to make after-dinner clean up fun!
Weekends are a great time for physical activity with the entire family. Spend the day together at a local park or a zoo :camping:.
Curious how to find whole grain foods? Look for 100% whole grain or 100% whole wheat on foods like bread, cereal, tortillas & pasta.
Set a healthy table & let everyone (kids too!) make choices about what they eat. It helps build confidence on how to eat healthy.
Get moving! Make a list of your family's favorite ways to be active. Each Saturday pick an activity out of a hat to do together.
Eating in front of the TV :tv: during meal and snack times can lead to overeating and weight gain as children get older. A great goal is no TV while eating.
Guide your preschooler's play. Add more challenging games such as catch with a foam ball :tennis: to help build his/her muscles and coordination.
Try to set screen time limits for the entire family. After the time is up, play board games or work on a puzzle together.
Family meals are a great time to role model healthy eating. Make sure your plate gets a serving of veggies too. Visit http://www.myplate.gov for ideas.
Did you know if the word "whole" is listed before the first ingredient then that food is made with whole grains?
Eat as a family :family: whenever you can. Keep meal time relaxed to nourish the body & help your family stay connected.
Limit buying unhealthy food at the store. If you don't have unhealthy options, your family will learn to choose healthy foods.
You praise {name} for all the wonderful things he/she can do. Praise yourself for making healthy decisions for your family.
Play with your food. Cut fruits and veggies into fun shapes. A kiwi into a star, melon :watermelon: a circle. Your 4yr old will love learning this way!
{name} looks up to you! Be a positive role model and avoid criticizing your own size, weight, and shape.
Help {name} understand that people come in many sizes and shapes. Lead by example and avoid talking negatively about others.
Try to limit TV :tv: and video games :video_game: to ones that encourage children to be active and act things out while watching TV or playing the game.
Focus on traits other than appearance when talking to {name}. Praise his/her good behavior or helpfulness with chores.
4-yr-olds love to help in the kitchen. Give small tasks such as mixing or pouring so they can get excited about the foods they eat.
Make snack time fun. Cut up vegetables to make a face. Cherry tomatoes can be eyes, carrot the nose and red pepper slice for a smile.
Many children with special needs can still play sports :person_with_ball:. Talk to your pediatrician about how to adapt sports to meet {name}'s needs.
:bulb: Activity idea! Let {name} help you clean the house. Give them small easy tasks such as sweeping or dusting to add activity to their day.
:point_right: Don't forget its time for {name}'s 5 year well child visit! Bring all your questions about keeping {name} eating healthy.
{name} now needs less fat than when he/she was younger. Lean meat (or equivalent) :meat_on_bone: is a great way to cut fat and provide a healthy option.
Happy 5th Birthday! :birthday: :gift: This is a big one! Wow! Have a great day & time celebrating.
:clap: Congratulations on staying with us this far and giving your family a great start to live a long & healthy life together!
